values.description:
I modified segway-posterior to output the segmentation produced by annotating each position with the highest-probability label at that position (also known as the posterior code), in addition to the posterior values, which it already outputs.  The posterior code file is output to path given with the --bed argument (outdir/segway.bed.gz by default).

In doing so, I also consolidated some duplicated code that appeared in both PosteriorSaver and IdentifySaver into a function called concatenate_window_segmentations().  

I submitted a pull request to the bitbucket repository.

Max
values.title: Modifying segway-posterior to output the posterior code

summary.raw:

The posterior code file is output to path given with the --bed argument (outdir/segway.bed.gz by default).

In doing so, I also consolidated some duplicated code that appeared in both PosteriorSaver and IdentifySaver into a function called concatenate_window_segmentations().  

I submitted a pull request to the bitbucket repository.

Max
summary.html:
I modified segway-posterior to output the segmentation produced by annotating each position with the highest-probability label at that position (also known as the posterior code), in addition to the posterior values, which it already outputs. The posterior code file is output to path given with the --bed argument (outdir/segway.bed.gz by default).

In doing so, I also consolidated some duplicated code that appeared in both PosteriorSaver and IdentifySaver into a function called concatenate_window_segmentations().

I submitted a pull request to the bitbucket repository.

Max

values.description:
Based on a user option, --output-label, the bed file will output either the superlabel only (default), the sublabel only, or both concatenated with a period. The tests produce the same result for me with and without these changes.

Update 2014-06-20
This is only done with the viterbi task for now, posterior will output superlabels only, and raise error if trying to do posterior and also trying to print sublabels. touchstone files are updated as a result of output_seg argument being passed, and viterbi regex filter which catches subseg and seg lines. Tests working now.
values.title: Code to output sublabels

values.description: Currently, in save_observation_params(), load_supervision() is called, which adds "supervisionLabel" to the list of tracknames if we are in semi-supervised mode, then set_tracknames() is called, which asserts that "supervisionLabel" is not in the list of tracknames. This assertion fails in semi supervised mode. We only want to prevent user-provided tracknames from having that special name, so the assertion should come when those tracknames are first read in.
values.title: Moved assertion to prevent error in semi supervised mode

summary.raw: Currently, in save_observation_params(), load_supervision() is called, which adds "supervisionLabel" to the list of tracknames if we are in semi-supervised mode, then set_tracknames() is called, which asserts that "supervisionLabel" is not in the list of tracknames. This assertion fails in semi supervised mode. We only want to prevent user-provided tracknames from having that special name, so the assertion should come when those tracknames are first read in.
summary.html: Currently, in save_observation_params(), load_supervision() is called, which adds "supervisionLabel" to the list of tracknames if we are in semi-supervised mode, then set_tracknames() is called, which asserts that "supervisionLabel" is not in the list of tracknames. This assertion fails in semi supervised mode. We only want to prevent user-provided tracknames from having that special name, so the assertion should come when those tracknames are first read in.

values.description: Now that the new sublabel behavior has been merged, I created a simplesubseg/ test in the same vein as the simpleseg/ test, using the same genomedata archive, but with 2 labels and 2 sublabels rather than 4 labels. On my machine this passes on repeated runs, and outputs all 4 sublabels in the viterbi output.
values.title: simplesubseg test

summary.raw: Now that the new sublabel behavior has been merged, I created a simplesubseg/ test in the same vein as the simpleseg/ test, using the same genomedata archive, but with 2 labels and 2 sublabels rather than 4 labels. On my machine this passes on repeated runs, and outputs all 4 sublabels in the viterbi output.
summary.html: Now that the new sublabel behavior has been merged, I created a simplesubseg/ test in the same vein as the simpleseg/ test, using the same genomedata archive, but with 2 labels and 2 sublabels rather than 4 labels. On my machine this passes on repeated runs, and outputs all 4 sublabels in the viterbi output.

values.reason: resubmitting based on a different development branch

values.description:
A previous pull request made the --output-label option control the output of the viterbi task, and this makes it work with the posterior task as well. In my testing this does not change segway's behavior unless the posterior task is specified, and output-label is not set to "seg". In sublabel output mode, the labels are printed according to the option in the posterior_code file, and separate posterior bed (and bedGraph) files are created for each sublabel. The "full" output mode (e.g. "0.1" for label 0 sublabel 1) seems a bit confusing for the bedGraph filenames, which already have periods in them, so I set the filenames to just be by sublabel (so for 2 labels and 2 sublabels, the bed files have names 0 through 3).

There is a minor change to a couple touchstone files to account for the fact that the num_subsegs variable is now passed to segway-task.
values.title: posterior compatibility with sublabel output mode

In my testing this does not change segway's behavior unless the posterior task is specified, and output-label is not set to "seg". In sublabel output mode, the labels are printed according to the option in the posterior_code file, and separate posterior bed (and bedGraph) files are created for each sublabel. The "full" output mode (e.g. "0.1" for label 0 sublabel 1) seems a bit confusing for the bedGraph filenames, which already have periods in them, so I set the filenames to just be by sublabel (so for 2 labels and 2 sublabels, the bed files have names 0 through 3).

There is a minor change to a couple touchstone files to account for the fact that the num_subsegs variable is now passed to segway-task.
summary.html:
A previous pull request made the --output-label option control the output of the viterbi task, and this makes it work with the posterior task as well. In my testing this does not change segway's behavior unless the posterior task is specified, and output-label is not set to "seg". In sublabel output mode, the labels are printed according to the option in the posterior_code file, and separate posterior bed (and bedGraph) files are created for each sublabel. The "full" output mode (e.g. "0.1" for label 0 sublabel 1) seems a bit confusing for the bedGraph filenames, which already have periods in them, so I set the filenames to just be by sublabel (so for 2 labels and 2 sublabels, the bed files have names 0 through 3).

There is a minor change to a couple touchstone files to account for the fact that the num_subsegs variable is now passed to segway-task.

values.description: This change is mainly for continuous integration. The test_all script would return a 0 exit status no matter what the exit status of the underlying tests run were. This just ensures a failure condition if any of the tests run under it fail.
values.title: Change test_all.sh script to return an non-zero error code if any of the tests run fail

summary.raw: This change is mainly for continuous integration. The test_all script would return a 0 exit status no matter what the exit status of the underlying tests run were. This just ensures a failure condition if any of the tests run under it fail.

values.description: Check if running the identify task, and if so, pass a cpp supervision label option to turn supervision off, so segway doesn't throw an error during the identify task if in semi-supervised mode. There is one line to add the constant for this value, 2 lines to assign the variable, and the rest are changes to touchstone files to account for the new cpp option being passed during the identify task.
values.title: semi-supervised identify fix

summary.raw: Check if running the identify task, and if so, pass a cpp supervision label option to turn supervision off, so segway doesn't throw an error during the identify task if in semi-supervised mode. There is one line to add the constant for this value, 2 lines to assign the variable, and the rest are changes to touchstone files to account for the new cpp option being passed during the identify task.
summary.html: Check if running the identify task, and if so, pass a cpp supervision label option to turn supervision off, so segway doesn't throw an error during the identify task if in semi-supervised mode. There is one line to add the constant for this value, 2 lines to assign the variable, and the rest are changes to touchstone files to account for the new cpp option being passed during the identify task.

values.description: I made a new pull request for this since all my recent work has been on this branch. The test runs the train task with semi-supervised mode enabled, and then runs identify and posterior in the "seg" and in the "full" output modes. It uses the same genomedata archive as the simpleseg test, except with 2 labels and 2 sublabels rather than 4 labels.
values.title: simplesubseg test

values.description:
This change modifies calc_version in setup.py to return a simple version
string when on tagged changeset that has not been modified (for a release).

There are a few caveats:

- In order for the version strings to show up normally, the current tagging
  convention has to change from a "release-{version}" to simply "{version}".
  This a documented aspect of hgtools.

- All modifications need to be committed, then tagged (which creates its own
  commit but will not commit any local changes) to ensure that that the
  version number tagged shows up correctly.

As far as the code change is concerned from looking through the
VersionManagement interface documented at
https://github.com/jaraco/hgtools/blob/master/hgtools/versioning.py (which
RepoManager inherits from and no-ops the remainder of the interface) I do not
know of a better way of detecting whether or not we're on an unmodified tagged
changeset or not other than checking the string returned (and if it ends with
'dev').
values.title: Change version calculation to include tagged versions

summary.raw:
This change modifies calc_version in setup.py to return a simple version
string when on tagged changeset that has not been modified (for a release).

There are a few caveats:

- In order for the version strings to show up normally, the current tagging
  convention has to change from a "release-{version}" to simply "{version}".
  This a documented aspect of hgtools.

- All modifications need to be committed, then tagged (which creates its own
  commit but will not commit any local changes) to ensure that that the
  version number tagged shows up correctly.

As far as the code change is concerned from looking through the
VersionManagement interface documented at
https://github.com/jaraco/hgtools/blob/master/hgtools/versioning.py (which
RepoManager inherits from and no-ops the remainder of the interface) I do not
know of a better way of detecting whether or not we're on an unmodified tagged
changeset or not other than checking the string returned (and if it ends with
'dev').
summary.html:
This change modifies calc_version in setup.py to return a simple version string when on tagged changeset that has not been modified (for a release).

There are a few caveats:

  • In order for the version strings to show up normally, the current tagging convention has to change from a "release-{version}" to simply "{version}". This a documented aspect of hgtools.

  • All modifications need to be committed, then tagged (which creates its own commit but will not commit any local changes) to ensure that that the version number tagged shows up correctly.

As far as the code change is concerned from looking through the VersionManagement interface documented at https://github.com/jaraco/hgtools/blob/master/hgtools/versioning.py (which RepoManager inherits from and no-ops the remainder of the interface) I do not know of a better way of detecting whether or not we're on an unmodified tagged changeset or not other than checking the string returned (and if it ends with 'dev').

These changes include new segmentation results and updated command parameters from recent segway changes.

I've verified test consistency between my local machine and the CI build:

values.description:
Update: commit 84706a8 is a small fix for BSD `find` compatibility

Update: segway_layer_bigbed test added.

Update: removed `-b` from test and bigBed file from touchstone.

Motivation for this patch: UCSC track hubs require bigBed files. segway 1.2 cannot generate bigBed files (see issue #22).

Patched layer.py to make sure that the segment added as a pad has length 1 instead of 0.
Updated segway.layered.bed and segway.layered.bb in test/segway_layer/touchstone. Tests pass.

Visual inspection of the old and new outputs in the browser shows that this creates a segment of length 1 at the first chromosomal coordinate. But I don't see any way around this, as bedToBigBed requires bedSizes > 0.

Another side effect is that I hard coded the `-b` option in the test, which means that 1 of the 2 tests will fail on machines where the `bedToBigBed` executable is not installed.
values.title: Fix layer.py / bigBed conversion (issue #22)

summary.raw:
Update: commit 84706a8 is a small fix for BSD `find` compatibility

Update: segway_layer_bigbed test added.

Update: removed `-b` from test and bigBed file from touchstone.

Motivation for this patch: UCSC track hubs require bigBed files. segway 1.2 cannot generate bigBed files (see issue #22).

Patched layer.py to make sure that the segment added as a pad has length 1 instead of 0.
Updated segway.layered.bed and segway.layered.bb in test/segway_layer/touchstone. Tests pass.

Visual inspection of the old and new outputs in the browser shows that this creates a segment of length 1 at the first chromosomal coordinate. But I don't see any way around this, as bedToBigBed requires bedSizes > 0.

Another side effect is that I hard coded the `-b` option in the test, which means that 1 of the 2 tests will fail on machines where the `bedToBigBed` executable is not installed.
summary.html:
Update: commit 84706a8 is a small fix for BSD find compatibility

Update: segway_layer_bigbed test added.

Update: removed -b from test and bigBed file from touchstone.

Motivation for this patch: UCSC track hubs require bigBed files. segway 1.2 cannot generate bigBed files (see issue #22).

Patched layer.py to make sure that the segment added as a pad has length 1 instead of 0. Updated segway.layered.bed and segway.layered.bb in test/segway_layer/touchstone. Tests pass.

Visual inspection of the old and new outputs in the browser shows that this creates a segment of length 1 at the first chromosomal coordinate. But I don't see any way around this, as bedToBigBed requires bedSizes > 0.

Another side effect is that I hard coded the -b option in the test, which means that 1 of the 2 tests will fail on machines where the bedToBigBed executable is not installed.

values.description:
To avoid further confusion with users accidentally tying tracks (or trying to use a recovery option) on the posterior task, error messages have been proposed in this pull request.

In order to specify the specific error the conditional had to be split to be more specific which error occurred and what has not yet been implemented.
values.title: Add helpful error messages to not yet implemented features for the posterior task

summary.raw:
To avoid further confusion with users accidentally tying tracks (or trying to use a recovery option) on the posterior task, error messages have been proposed in this pull request.

In order to specify the specific error the conditional had to be split to be more specific which error occurred and what has not yet been implemented.
summary.html:
To avoid further confusion with users accidentally tying tracks (or trying to use a recovery option) on the posterior task, error messages have been proposed in this pull request.

In order to specify the specific error the conditional had to be split to be more specific which error occurred and what has not yet been implemented.

values.description:
Currently the only reliable way to build documentation with the help text included is to use the Makefile. As far as I can tell this is a slightly deprecated method of building docs and using 'sphinx-build' should be preferred (which make ultimately calls).

This change modifies the the conf.py used by sphinx-build to ensure that the necessary commands have their command help text generated in a way that's compatible with the old Makefile and current documentation.
values.title: Add fix for sphinx-build to correctly add command line help information in documentation

summary.raw:
Currently the only reliable way to build documentation with the help text included is to use the Makefile. As far as I can tell this is a slightly deprecated method of building docs and using 'sphinx-build' should be preferred (which make ultimately calls).

This change modifies the the conf.py used by sphinx-build to ensure that the necessary commands have their command help text generated in a way that's compatible with the old Makefile and current documentation.
summary.html:
Currently the only reliable way to build documentation with the help text included is to use the Makefile. As far as I can tell this is a slightly deprecated method of building docs and using 'sphinx-build' should be preferred (which make ultimately calls).

This change modifies the the conf.py used by sphinx-build to ensure that the necessary commands have their command help text generated in a way that's compatible with the old Makefile and current documentation.

values.description: Currently exported functions (which start with the name BASH_FUNC) since the shellshock patch do not export correctly to some DRM systems. Since the goal is to have segway to work on as many clusters as possible I believe we can safely filter out any bash functions (BASH_FUNC) from our exported environment. We'll maintain any loaded environment settings but not any functions. This way we'll also avoid any users locally defined functions from potentially causing errors in the future.
values.title: Remove shellshock exported shell functions submitted job environments

summary.raw: Currently exported functions (which start with the name BASH_FUNC) since the shellshock patch do not export correctly to some DRM systems. Since the goal is to have segway to work on as many clusters as possible I believe we can safely filter out any bash functions (BASH_FUNC) from our exported environment. We'll maintain any loaded environment settings but not any functions. This way we'll also avoid any users locally defined functions from potentially causing errors in the future.
summary.html: Currently exported functions (which start with the name BASH_FUNC) since the shellshock patch do not export correctly to some DRM systems. Since the goal is to have segway to work on as many clusters as possible I believe we can safely filter out any bash functions (BASH_FUNC) from our exported environment. We'll maintain any loaded environment settings but not any functions. This way we'll also avoid any users locally defined functions from potentially causing errors in the future.

values.description:
This adds additional classifier information when searching for segway on PyPI for future releases

```shell
$ python setup.py --classifiers
Natural Language :: English
Development Status :: 5 - Production/Stable
Intended Audience :: Science/Research
License :: OSI Approved :: GNU General Public License v2 (GPLv2)
Topic :: Scientific/Engineering :: Bio-Informatics
Operating System :: Unix
Programming Language :: Python
Programming Language :: Python 2
```

values.description: Deal with #32. Fixed in the easiest way. I am not sure if this is the best way. It seems like it had been the case that segway treat ```traindir/likelihood/likelihood.0.ll``` as the final winning likelihood file. If we decide to keep that feature (which doesn’t look cool to me since we are basically trying to erase a likelihood data), then adding a simple line to detect if the file name are the same should work. If they are, then we are confident that likelihood.0.ll is the winning method and we can just keep this file.
values.title: Add a detect before doing copy

summary.raw: Deal with #32. Fixed in the easiest way. I am not sure if this is the best way. It seems like it had been the case that segway treat ```traindir/likelihood/likelihood.0.ll``` as the final winning likelihood file. If we decide to keep that feature (which doesn’t look cool to me since we are basically trying to erase a likelihood data), then adding a simple line to detect if the file name are the same should work. If they are, then we are confident that likelihood.0.ll is the winning method and we can just keep this file.
summary.html: Deal with #32. Fixed in the easiest way. I am not sure if this is the best way. It seems like it had been the case that segway treat traindir/likelihood/likelihood.0.ll as the final winning likelihood file. If we decide to keep that feature (which doesn’t look cool to me since we are basically trying to erase a likelihood data), then adding a simple line to detect if the file name are the same should work. If they are, then we are confident that likelihood.0.ll is the winning method and we can just keep this file.

values.reason: Use other way to fix it

values.description:
Fix for #32.

The solution is to change the final likelihood filename. The reason why this easy fix work is because ```set_log_lielihood``` is called withouth parameter IFF on the main thread.  And make_filename will simply ignore all instances that is None by its implementation.

There is a issue regarding of changing it this way. Likelihood Tab file is also generated through ```set_log_likelihood``` method. Modifying that will change the original ```log/likelihood.0.tab``` in single thread mode to ```log/likelihood.tab```.

This does not affect multiple instances since on multiple instances main thread do not take training job and all instances will call this function with a real-valued ```instance_index```

This will at least cause all current test would failed since ```likelihood.tab``` can't be align with ```likelihood.0.tab``` even if they have the exact same content. We could rewrite all the touchstone, or we may consider if we need to make sure that our modification does not change the tab file in single instance mode.
values.title: Fix Same File Error by change log likelihood filename.

summary.raw:
Fix for #32.

The solution is to change the final likelihood filename. The reason why this easy fix work is because ```set_log_lielihood``` is called withouth parameter IFF on the main thread.  And make_filename will simply ignore all instances that is None by its implementation.

There is a issue regarding of changing it this way. Likelihood Tab file is also generated through ```set_log_likelihood``` method. Modifying that will change the original ```log/likelihood.0.tab``` in single thread mode to ```log/likelihood.tab```.

This does not affect multiple instances since on multiple instances main thread do not take training job and all instances will call this function with a real-valued ```instance_index```

This will at least cause all current test would failed since ```likelihood.tab``` can't be align with ```likelihood.0.tab``` even if they have the exact same content. We could rewrite all the touchstone, or we may consider if we need to make sure that our modification does not change the tab file in single instance mode.
summary.html:
Fix for #32.

The solution is to change the final likelihood filename. The reason why this easy fix work is because set_log_lielihood is called withouth parameter IFF on the main thread. And make_filename will simply ignore all instances that is None by its implementation.

There is a issue regarding of changing it this way. Likelihood Tab file is also generated through set_log_likelihood method. Modifying that will change the original log/likelihood.0.tab in single thread mode to log/likelihood.tab.

This does not affect multiple instances since on multiple instances main thread do not take training job and all instances will call this function with a real-valued instance_index

This will at least cause all current test would failed since likelihood.tab can't be align with likelihood.0.tab even if they have the exact same content. We could rewrite all the touchstone, or we may consider if we need to make sure that our modification does not change the tab file in single instance mode.

values.description: This changes compare_directory.py to use a line-by-line comparision when files do not match and reports on a line-by-line difference. This makes finding differences/errors significantly faster.
values.title: Add line reporting when comparing directories for testing

summary.raw: This changes compare_directory.py to use a line-by-line comparision when files do not match and reports on a line-by-line difference. This makes finding differences/errors significantly faster.
summary.html: This changes compare_directory.py to use a line-by-line comparision when files do not match and reports on a line-by-line difference. This makes finding differences/errors significantly faster.

values.description:
This is a follow up to Issue 32 and Pull Request 20. 

Part of the fix to Issue 32 in Pull Request 20 cause the following autobuild failure in test case simplerecover

```
#!

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/bin/segway", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('segway==1.2.2.dev0', 'console_scripts', 'segway')()
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/segway-1.2.2.dev0-py2.7.egg/segway/run.py", line 2583, in main
    return runner()
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/segway-1.2.2.dev0-py2.7.egg/segway/run.py", line 2395, in __call__
    self.run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/segway-1.2.2.dev0-py2.7.egg/segway/run.py", line 2361, in run
    self.run_train()
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/segway-1.2.2.dev0-py2.7.egg/segway/run.py", line 1948, in run_train
    instance_params = run_train_func(self.num_segs_range)
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/segway-1.2.2.dev0-py2.7.egg/segway/run.py", line 1957, in run_train_singlethread
    res = [self.run_train_instance()]
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/segway-1.2.2.dev0-py2.7.egg/segway/run.py", line 1819, in run_train_instance
    self.make_instance_initial_results()
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/segway-1.2.2.dev0-py2.7.egg/segway/run.py", line 2129, in make_instance_initial_results
    log_likelihood)
  File "/home/ubuntu/virtualenv/python2.7/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/segway-1.2.2.dev0-py2.7.egg/segway/run.py", line 2087, in recover_train_instance
    with open(recover_log_likelihood_tab_filepath) \
IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: path('../recover/traindir/log/likelihood.0.tab')
```

The cause of this error is because we decide to let likelihood tab file have the same name as the likelihood file. In this case, its trying to recover a single-instance run, where the likelihood file has been renamed to likelihood.ll so the tab file name lis likelihood.tab.

The fix might seems “bad”, but that’s the only good one I could think of for now.

The root cause of this problem and the Issue 32 is the fundamental difference how segway treat single instance and multiple instances. Despite the fact that the main run function of the two are the same, in multi instance case it use the result of set_log_likelihood_filenames call in the main run function, while in single instance, this function is called but ignored. They also have a different way wrap up after the main part of training has finished, where likelihood file is not wrapped up at the end of the single instance case. The best way to fix this is to refactoring the whole part which would be extremely costly and I would not recommend that.
values.title: Fix the autobuild won't pass caused by could not find tab file by adding a test to see if the file exists.

Despite the fact that the main run function of the two are the same, in multi instance case it use the result of set_log_likelihood_filenames call in the main run function, while in single instance, this function is called but ignored. They also have a different way wrap up after the main part of training has finished, where likelihood file is not wrapped up at the end of the single instance case. values.description:
Issue #37

This is the implementation of generate track mean for supervision label based on track data only in supervision region instead of the whole track.
I am not sure whether it should be permanent feature or my hacky approach but I'll setup the Issue & pull request first.

Now there is a new parameter added to the main segway function: ```--set-supervision-mean```.
If set, the base mean for all track for each label with semi-supervision present will be the mean of the track data in the supervision region. The real mean will be still added by std * rand(-0.2, 0.2) because I want to still keep some randomness. The std here is still generate by the whole track and there the reason why I did not change it is stated below.

I did not generate a Gaussian variance only from the supervision region. I do think it is useful to add that feature but the current the variance seems to be uniform at first for all label, generating it in different way seems to require changing the structure of input-master file which I don't have time to do. Also if this would be a permanent feature then there is a problem we have to consider if we do it this way: what if we only have a very small supervision region? Variance could be 0. 

If not set, everything is the same.

Some other important issue of this modification:
1. It does not support subseg
2. It does not support Trackgroup

I am not sure how the behaviour should be defined when subseg and Trackgroup is used.
values.title: Semisupervised Mean Generate from Track data in supervision region.

summary.raw:
Issue #37

This is the implementation of generate track mean for supervision label based on track data only in supervision region instead of the whole track.
I am not sure whether it should be permanent feature or my hacky approach but I'll setup the Issue & pull request first.

Now there is a new parameter added to the main segway function: ```--set-supervision-mean```.
If set, the base mean for all track for each label with semi-supervision present will be the mean of the track data in the supervision region. The real mean will be still added by std * rand(-0.2, 0.2) because I want to still keep some randomness. The std here is still generate by the whole track and there the reason why I did not change it is stated below.

I did not generate a Gaussian variance only from the supervision region. I do think it is useful to add that feature but the current the variance seems to be uniform at first for all label, generating it in different way seems to require changing the structure of input-master file which I don't have time to do. Also if this would be a permanent feature then there is a problem we have to consider if we do it this way: what if we only have a very small supervision region? Variance could be 0. 

If not set, everything is the same.

Some other important issue of this modification:
1. It does not support subseg
2. It does not support Trackgroup

I am not sure how the behaviour should be defined when subseg and Trackgroup is used.
summary.html:
Issue #37

This is the implementation of generate track mean for supervision label based on track data only in supervision region instead of the whole track. I am not sure whether it should be permanent feature or my hacky approach but I'll setup the Issue & pull request first.

Now there is a new parameter added to the main segway function: --set-supervision-mean. If set, the base mean for all track for each label with semi-supervision present will be the mean of the track data in the supervision region. The real mean will be still added by std * rand(-0.2, 0.2) because I want to still keep some randomness. The std here is still generate by the whole track and there the reason why I did not change it is stated below.

I did not generate a Gaussian variance only from the supervision region. I do think it is useful to add that feature but the current the variance seems to be uniform at first for all label, generating it in different way seems to require changing the structure of input-master file which I don't have time to do. Also if this would be a permanent feature then there is a problem we have to consider if we do it this way: what if we only have a very small supervision region? Variance could be 0.

If not set, everything is the same.

Some other important issue of this modification: 1. It does not support subseg 2. It does not support Trackgroup

I am not sure how the behaviour should be defined when subseg and Trackgroup is used.

values.description:
Issue #38

This is the implementation for the soft labelling of segway semi-supervised mode.
Now you can specify soft label assignment in the supervision BED file.
If you have ```0``` as the name, it will be the same as it was.
But know you could make the name look like ```0:5``` to specify anything in the range ```[0,5) == 0,1,2,3,4```

Currently it only support soft assignment with the same width, but I'll add more complex support in future update once I realize how to add data structure in tmpl file.

This current version can't pass the unit test because it modified the segway.inc file structure. Since it took a while to change that I would only update the test case until we reach an agreement on what I changed here.
values.title: Implement the first simple version of soft label

summary.raw:
Issue #38

This is the implementation for the soft labelling of segway semi-supervised mode.
Now you can specify soft label assignment in the supervision BED file.
If you have ```0``` as the name, it will be the same as it was.
But know you could make the name look like ```0:5``` to specify anything in the range ```[0,5) == 0,1,2,3,4```

Currently it only support soft assignment with the same width, but I'll add more complex support in future update once I realize how to add data structure in tmpl file.

This current version can't pass the unit test because it modified the segway.inc file structure. Since it took a while to change that I would only update the test case until we reach an agreement on what I changed here.
summary.html:
Issue #38

This is the implementation for the soft labelling of segway semi-supervised mode. Now you can specify soft label assignment in the supervision BED file. If you have 0 as the name, it will be the same as it was. But know you could make the name look like 0:5 to specify anything in the range [0,5) == 0,1,2,3,4

Currently it only support soft assignment with the same width, but I'll add more complex support in future update once I realize how to add data structure in tmpl file.

This current version can't pass the unit test because it modified the segway.inc file structure. Since it took a while to change that I would only update the test case until we reach an agreement on what I changed here.

values.description:
This pull request is initial implementation of allowing mulitple genomedatas with the same reference sequence to incorporate unique track names across archives.

Both training and identify/viterbi have been tested. Posterior has not been implemented (or tested) at the moment. Track groups should be possible across archives.

I've omitted the changes necessary to the NEWS and documentation for now until there's an agreed upon set of changes in case there are any details in terms of interface or implementation that change while the pull request is in discussion.

* Rename save_observation_params to save_gmtk_input

* Add initial test of segway handling multiple genomedata archives

* Change test to use one track per genomedata archive.
    Change set_tracknames in run.py to handle multiple genomedata archives.
    Change subset_metadata to handle multiple genomedata archives.

* Remove singular genome parameter from subset_metadata_attr

* Update Observation.save to save observations across multiple genomedata archives.
    Update genomedata archives used in mulitpledatasets testcase

* Remove extraneous genomedata and bed files in multipledatasets test case.
    Add initial implementation of identify with multiple genomedata archives.

* Clean up multidata testcase script.
* Fix identify support for single and multiple genomedata archives
values.title: Multiple Genomedata datasets

Both training and identify/viterbi have been tested. Posterior has not been implemented (or tested) at the moment. Track groups should be possible across archives.

I've omitted the changes necessary to the NEWS and documentation for now until there's an agreed upon set of changes in case there are any details in terms of interface or implementation that change while the pull request is in discussion.

* Rename save_observation_params to save_gmtk_input

summary.html:
This pull request is initial implementation of allowing mulitple genomedatas with the same reference sequence to incorporate unique track names across archives.

Both training and identify/viterbi have been tested. Posterior has not been implemented (or tested) at the moment. Track groups should be possible across archives.

I've omitted the changes necessary to the NEWS and documentation for now until there's an agreed upon set of changes in case there are any details in terms of interface or implementation that change while the pull request is in discussion.

  • Rename save_observation_params to save_gmtk_input

  • Add initial test of segway handling multiple genomedata archives

  • Change test to use one track per genomedata archive. Change set_tracknames in run.py to handle multiple genomedata archives. Change subset_metadata to handle multiple genomedata archives.

  • Remove singular genome parameter from subset_metadata_attr

  • Update Observation.save to save observations across multiple genomedata archives. Update genomedata archives used in mulitpledatasets testcase

  • Remove extraneous genomedata and bed files in multipledatasets test case. Add initial implementation of identify with multiple genomedata archives.

  • Clean up multidata testcase script.

  • Fix identify support for single and multiple genomedata archives

This pull request fixes the syntax highlighting of the environment variables through the documentation by using the :envvar: directive/domain.

It adds it's own section for Environment Variables below the command line usage summary and references to the variables link there.

values.description:
In reference to Issue #49

Currently segway selects the first genomedata archive found for each track specified. It should report an error if the track is found across multiple archives.
values.title: Fix case where a track is specified that exists in more than one genomedata

summary.raw:
In reference to Issue #49

Currently segway selects the first genomedata archive found for each track specified. It should report an error if the track is found across multiple archives.
summary.html:
In reference to Issue #49

Currently segway selects the first genomedata archive found for each track specified. It should report an error if the track is found across multiple archives.

values.description:
* Commit initial implementation and tests of GMTK error reports

    Adds a simplebadinput test to check for proper termination on a GMTK job
    submitted error. Adds documentation specifying how to better debug GMTK
    errors. Adds support to catch out of memory errors in GTMK versions 1.4.3 or
    above. Adds a better error message for errors that are not due to being out of
    memory.

* Add simple job resubmission test

* Add mininum constant for number of resubmittable job attempts per job.

* Add GMTK version checking during install. Change max job attempts to 2.

* Update NEWS
values.title: Better GMTK Job handling

summary.raw:
* Commit initial implementation and tests of GMTK error reports

    Adds a simplebadinput test to check for proper termination on a GMTK job
    submitted error. Adds documentation specifying how to better debug GMTK
    errors. Adds support to catch out of memory errors in GTMK versions 1.4.3 or
    above. Adds a better error message for errors that are not due to being out of
    memory.

* Add simple job resubmission test

* Add mininum constant for number of resubmittable job attempts per job.

* Add GMTK version checking during install. Change max job attempts to 2.

* Update NEWS
summary.html:
• Commit initial implementation and tests of GMTK error reports

    Adds a simplebadinput test to check for proper termination on a GMTK job submitted error. Adds documentation specifying how to better debug GMTK errors. Adds support to catch out of memory errors in GTMK versions 1.4.3 or above. Adds a better error message for errors that are not due to being out of memory.

  • Add simple job resubmission test

  • Add mininum constant for number of resubmittable job attempts per job.

  • Add GMTK version checking during install. Change max job attempts to 2.

  • Update NEWS

values.description: I implemented minibatch training in the Segway trunk, where each training iteration uses a random subset of the include_coords windows rather than all of them.  Minibatch training allows training to touch every position in the genome while maintaining fast iterations.  It is controlled with the --minibatch-num-windows option.  It selects random windows from --include-coords, so you want to use the full genome for --include-coords.  Likelihood-based stopping criterion is no longer valid with minibatch training, so I made it so that it always to max-train-rounds if --minibatch-num-windows is set.
values.title: Minibatch training

summary.raw: I implemented minibatch training in the Segway trunk, where each training iteration uses a random subset of the include_coords windows rather than all of them.  Minibatch training allows training to touch every position in the genome while maintaining fast iterations.  It is controlled with the --minibatch-num-windows option.  It selects random windows from --include-coords, so you want to use the full genome for --include-coords.  Likelihood-based stopping criterion is no longer valid with minibatch training, so I made it so that it always to max-train-rounds if --minibatch-num-windows is set.
summary.html: I implemented minibatch training in the Segway trunk, where each training iteration uses a random subset of the include_coords windows rather than all of them. Minibatch training allows training to touch every position in the genome while maintaining fast iterations. It is controlled with the --minibatch-num-windows option. It selects random windows from --include-coords, so you want to use the full genome for --include-coords. Likelihood-based stopping criterion is no longer valid with minibatch training, so I made it so that it always to max-train-rounds if --minibatch-num-windows is set.

values.description: Bugfix of a special case where the ruler-scale is automatically adjusted (10*resolution) even if the user set the ruler-scale to 10. For example if the resolution and the ruler-scale are manually set to 10, the ruler-scale will automatically be 100. The issue is that the condition to auto-adjust the ruler-scale is set to check differences between the default ruler-scale value and the res.ruler_scale which is by default 10 if not specified by the user. The solution here is to check the options.ruler_scale which is None is not specified by the user.
values.title: auto adjust the ruler-scale only if a rule-scale is not specified by the user

summary.raw: Bugfix of a special case where the ruler-scale is automatically adjusted (10*resolution) even if the user set the ruler-scale to 10. For example if the resolution and the ruler-scale are manually set to 10, the ruler-scale will automatically be 100. The issue is that the condition to auto-adjust the ruler-scale is set to check differences between the default ruler-scale value and the res.ruler_scale which is by default 10 if not specified by the user. The solution here is to check the options.ruler_scale which is None is not specified by the user.
summary.html: Bugfix of a special case where the ruler-scale is automatically adjusted (10*resolution) even if the user set the ruler-scale to 10. For example if the resolution and the ruler-scale are manually set to 10, the ruler-scale will automatically be 100. The issue is that the condition to auto-adjust the ruler-scale is set to check differences between the default ruler-scale value and the res.ruler_scale which is by default 10 if not specified by the user. The solution here is to check the options.ruler_scale which is None is not specified by the user.

values.description:
* Refactor optparse/optplus to use argparse instead

It's worth noting that `optplus` is still needed as a dependency but *only* for the `str2slice_or_int` function which is imported from that module.

All tests currently pass.
values.title: Optparse to argparse refactor

summary.raw:

It's worth noting that `optplus` is still needed as a dependency but *only* for the `str2slice_or_int` function which is imported from that module.

All tests currently pass.
summary.html:
• Refactor optparse/optplus to use argparse instead

It's worth noting that optplus is still needed as a dependency but only for the str2slice_or_int function which is imported from that module.

All tests currently pass.

values.description:
Currently optbuild doesn't cause a EX_TEMPFAIL exit from segway-task when gmtkViterbi is out of memory. Instead an exception like this is raised:

"optbuild.ReturncodeError: /mnt/work1/users/home2/mickaelm/lib/bin/gmtkViterbi returned 75"

The exception itself causes an error code of 1. We're more interested in getting the actual return code to see if we should resubmit due to out of memory.

This pull request also fixes the SIGKILL detection of segway-task.

Note that this doesn't attempt to catch the optbuild.SignalError. As in it doesn't catch a SIGKILL on gmtkViterbi. However the SIGKILL will catch on segway-task which runs gmtkViterbi.

No NEWS changes are needed since this falls under the news item:
"* segway: add and fix better job handling for segway-task (identify)"
values.title: Fix catching SIGKILL from segway-task and propagating non-zero exit status from gmtkViterbi

summary.raw:
Currently optbuild doesn't cause a EX_TEMPFAIL exit from segway-task when gmtkViterbi is out of memory. Instead an exception like this is raised:

"optbuild.ReturncodeError: /mnt/work1/users/home2/mickaelm/lib/bin/gmtkViterbi returned 75"

The exception itself causes an error code of 1. We're more interested in getting the actual return code to see if we should resubmit due to out of memory.

This pull request also fixes the SIGKILL detection of segway-task.

Note that this doesn't attempt to catch the optbuild.SignalError. As in it doesn't catch a SIGKILL on gmtkViterbi. However the SIGKILL will catch on segway-task which runs gmtkViterbi.

No NEWS changes are needed since this falls under the news item:
"* segway: add and fix better job handling for segway-task (identify)"
summary.html:
Currently optbuild doesn't cause a EX_TEMPFAIL exit from segway-task when gmtkViterbi is out of memory. Instead an exception like this is raised:

"optbuild.ReturncodeError: /mnt/work1/users/home2/mickaelm/lib/bin/gmtkViterbi returned 75"

The exception itself causes an error code of 1. We're more interested in getting the actual return code to see if we should resubmit due to out of memory.

This pull request also fixes the SIGKILL detection of segway-task.

Note that this doesn't attempt to catch the optbuild.SignalError. As in it doesn't catch a SIGKILL on gmtkViterbi. However the SIGKILL will catch on segway-task which runs gmtkViterbi.

No NEWS changes are needed since this falls under the news item: "* segway: add and fix better job handling for segway-task (identify)"

values.description:
This pull request addresses Issue #1. It rearranges the code to fix missing methods required for the `--prior-strength` option.

It's important to note that there are no current tests for `--prior-strength`. The resulting segmentation with a --prior-strength of 0.7 on simpleseg produced an identical segmentation then it would have without.
values.title: Fix prior-strength option

summary.raw:
This pull request addresses Issue #1. It rearranges the code to fix missing methods required for the `--prior-strength` option.

It's important to note that there are no current tests for `--prior-strength`. The resulting segmentation with a --prior-strength of 0.7 on simpleseg produced an identical segmentation then it would have without.
summary.html:
This pull request addresses Issue #1. It rearranges the code to fix missing methods required for the --prior-strength option.

It's important to note that there are no current tests for --prior-strength. The resulting segmentation with a --prior-strength of 0.7 on simpleseg produced an identical segmentation then it would have without.

values.description: This pull request changes so jobs run locally do not clear out the error logs on job resubmission and instead append their output to the error log for the same job.
values.title: Change local job resubmission to append stderr logs

values.description:
This pull request adds resolution>1 functionality for semisupervised mode by downsampling supervision label data to desired resolution by mode. Previously this was not implemented yet and only worked for resolution=1. 

Another question is if the gold standard for test/simplesemisupervised should be modified to accommodate for >1 resolution.
values.title: Resolution option functionality for semi-supervised mode

summary.raw:
This pull request adds resolution>1 functionality for semisupervised mode by downsampling supervision label data to desired resolution by mode. Previously this was not implemented yet and only worked for resolution=1. 

Another question is if the gold standard for test/simplesemisupervised should be modified to accommodate for >1 resolution.
summary.html:
This pull request adds resolution>1 functionality for semisupervised mode by downsampling supervision label data to desired resolution by mode. Previously this was not implemented yet and only worked for resolution=1.

Another question is if the gold standard for test/simplesemisupervised should be modified to accommodate for >1 resolution.

values.description:
Updated GMTK version for quickstart. Updated segway documentation to briefly explain semisupervised resolution functionality.

Did not mention weighting of alwaysTrue variable with presence of supervision labels since presence/weighting of other data tracks is not mentioned either in the documentation.
values.title: Updated segway documentation to briefly explain semisupervised resolution functionality.
